headline: This is the Laptop you’re looking for
text: I love this laptop. No complaints. I know people will complain about the weight or how hot the computer gets. Its a laptop with an intel and monster hardware of course it’s going to get hot depending on various factors. For small activities such as, surfing the internet or doing homework it doesn’t get hot for me. I use this more for gaming, I do have it on a cooling pad and it doesn’t get hot unless I play a quality hungry game at max settings like Cyberpunk. I did get this laptop on sale thats why I ending up grabbing it at my local BB for a steal of a deal. If you do buy this laptop (or any ASUS gaming laptop) I recommend you to delete Asus armoury crate and it’s sister applications to download G helper instead. The best program to have on these gaming asus laptops. If you can find this product for a deal or if you have the money to spend I say get this laptop for sure.

headline: Fast with cool RGB
text: This laptop would have a perfect 5/5 star review if the ports didnt feel loose. Other than that this laptop is the perfect desktop replacement paired with a external monitor if you want home performance as well as mobility. Its able to play 4k games with an external monitor at 100 fps and 2k games at 160+ fps. I recommend buying an external laptop cooler if you want longevity for your gaming investment. The ASUS software to control the RGB and settings is very premium and highly customizable. You'll get lost just playing with the settings and staring at the lights lol. No... seriously the RGB is like a light show at a rave.

Sometimes excellent isn't really excellent in my opinion but they seem to be improving in that regard.

headline: TERRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE.
text: Laptop had a bad battery when I purchased it. I diagnosed it myself as I know about computers. Purchased as an open box and took it into best buy the following day to have them check it and replace the battery. They told me they wouldn't replace the battery and if I wanted the laptop I just spent close to $2,500 to work I needed to pay for it to be fixed. Understandably I got upset and left and bought a battery swapped it myself. WORKS LIKE A DREAM NOW! This review isn't a reflection of the product as the laptop is great! However best buys customer service is complete GARBAGE. If I hadn't disclosed the battery was bad and just returned it they would've taken it and given me my money back however I just wanted them to fix it as I wanted to keep it. Avoid the Best Buy in arden fair, CA the geek squad team there is horrible and 0 knowledge on electronics as well as the staff and management is horrible.

headline: Bloatware caused countless problems
text: The screen switching gpu tech was horrid, caused countless freezes for nearly 5-10 seconds a piece. After 3 days with the product and disabling and uninstalling more automatic "performance features" it felt okay..but the magic was lost. I was upset already. returned it. maybe it won't bother you and it will be awesome. For me it was a nightmare to have to uninstall and configure for 3 days to get it working "fine"

headline: Maximum PWNAGE!
text:
I am always impressed how Asus keeps raising the bar, over and over and over!  I've been a hug Asus fan for over a decade.  I use their motherboards (Strix and TUF), video cards, power supplies and even some peripherals.   When I need a laptop I've had a few other brands but always gravitate to Asus.  Vivobooks are an awesome value for business or school but gaming laptops always push boundaries.  I think my first gaming laptop was a G1 and everyone thought it was an AW.  Stylish and powerful.  What more do you need?

I've settled in on Strix and Zephyrus laptops as my workhorse... for both work and play.  The 16" are luggable and great for work.  Not too heavy or bulky and fit most laptop bags.  The 18" variants are more of a desktop replacement but even still, if determined, you can lug them just as easily but you need a spacious bag.  

The specs on this beast are amazing.   Cram the Intel Ultra 9 HX into the case along with 32GB of replaceable DDR5-5600 SODIMM memory, a nVidia GeForce RTX5080 (mobile chip) and yes... finally a 2TB SSD.  I was always stymied why manufacturers were stuffing 512GB or if lucky 1TB SSDs in a gaming laptop.  Storage is key for a high performance gaming system... a lot of the AAA games take up gobs of space so the 2TB is welcome!!!!  Even better is there is a spare NVME M.2  drive slot for an easy way to add to your storage.  Back on memory for a second, the growing trend of soldering in at least one stick of RAM onto the motherboard is horrible and Asus doesn't bend to that practice, keeping with replaceable SODIMM sticks.  

While my previous Zephyrus G16 go scorching hot in the space between the keyboard and screen.  That is not the case with this one.  Cooling has gotten much better... more heat pipes that move the generated heat easily out of the shell.  

Pairing the RTX5080 with the 240Hz IPS display at 3ms response time gives you the awe-factor you look for in gaming.  The 16:10 aspect ratio at 2560 x 1600 2.5K screen produces amazing clarity and 500 nits of brightness produces bright colors.  Along with all the other hardware produces amazing frame rates and of course that depends on what game you are playing.  

Lots of RGB but glad it doesn't have the annoying lit slash on the lid that last year's Zephyrus had.  Turned that off quickly!  The keyboard has programmable RGB and I really love the translucent WASD-RF-Space keys.  I use the numpad for work so the G18 gets me that with the extra real estate over the G16.

Plenty of I/O ports that make connectivity a breeze.  Left side you have power (rectangular connector instead of the usual barrel), ethernet, HDMI 2.1, USB-A 3.2, 2 Thunderbolt USB-Cs and headphone jack.  On the right there are 2 USB-A 3.2.  Wifi-7 provides the fast network connection needed when playing demanding games as long as your wifi system supports the faster speeds.  

Upgrading this system is a breeze.  Gone are the bazillion case screens... okay... maybe 12 that you have to not lose and them grab the guitar picks and pry the bottom off.  No sir, now it's a simple slide button on the bottom towards the front and once slid into the unlock position you slide the bottom forward and it's off.  I personally don't see the need to upgrade the memory but you can definitely add that second NVME drive.  For me... I tossed in a 4TB SSD and slid the bottom back on and the latch snapped to the locked position.

Sound from the speakers is okay, could use a bit more bass for my liking but still more than adequate and nothing really to complain about.

All in all bravo Asus.  A well designed and beastly equipped machine.

headline: Performance - by the pound!
text:
To reiterate the title - for every ounce of weight of this laptop (omg is it heavy), you will get top rated gaming performance.  I guess if you're into weighted blankets, you would want this on your lap while in use.  Other than that, some other downsides:

-You're going to want to plug this in unless you're gaming for only like an hour at a time
-Fan noise can get high
-Puts off some heat

I loaded up Elder Scrolls Oblivion Remastered from XBox GamePass as I heard it is a machine crippler - I don't think I've ever seen such a beautiful game delivered without any sort of performance hit in the least.  The visuals were great, though some may want to try to make the blacks 'blacker'.  Absolutely no tearing of any kind.  Sound was great for a laptop, though I'd suspect most gamers would be wielding headsets anyway.  In the same vain, the touchpad - which worked as expected - is not something I would ever use while gaming - it just seemed to take up more space than needed.  I hooked up an XBox game controller via Bluetooth without any issues.

Lots of hard drive space to fill up with games.

Lots of customization options with the built in Asus apps.  If you're into LEDs, there's loads of them.  I liked the treatment of them for the AWSD keys which are normally used for movement.  The one 'gimmick' I wasn't a huge fan of was the laser light show the laptop generated while sitting idle.  I just haven't taken the time to see if that was a thing I could disable.  Other than that, the laptop looks great in general.

Other highlights:
-Ethernet port
-Charging cord length was good, though the power brick - again - heavy/big.
-Tool-less entry was a little fiddly but once you get it, it is nice, though I don't know what I'd be doing inside this machine anytime soon

headline: This is a gaming monster!
text:
To do this review, I had my gamer son assist me in testing the Asus ROG Strix G18 and I wrote the review based on our mutual thoughts on the computer. I would consider myself average to somewhat advanced gamer, but my son is next level and is pretty gifted at gaming (and humbles me quicker than I care to admit). So, this is an honest review from someone that was extremely impressed with this computer and logged a lot of RPG hours in doing this review. When I look for a gaming computer, I want something that can pull it's weight. With tech always getting bigger, better and faster, it often comes down to a few brands and Asus is always a brand to look at first. The Asus ROG Strix G18 is more than just a strong performer, it feels like it was legitimately made with gamers in mind. Like taking feedback from the field and applying those considerations. It incorporates the top hardware, an advanced cooling system, a superior display, and a top-quality build. For me as a gamer/reviewer this is the best gaming computer I personally have had the chance to review. In this review I will focus on the Processor, GPU, cooling system, the display and build quality. I will then tell you why I like it so much. You can then decide if it would be a good option for you. 

The heart of the G18 is the Intel Core i9-13980HX. The 24 core (not a typo) processor is among the most powerful processors on the market today. That includes 8 performance cores and 16 efficiency cores. Performance cores handle the demanding tasks and are faster, while the efficiency cores are just that, more efficient and handle the background tasks. For a gamer, this means more than simply high frame rates. It means you can multitask. Specifically, you can game, stream, record and/or browse with superior performance, without slowing your system down. I tested this playing a few different FPS games with the setting placed on high. I had various chrome tabs open, running OBS to stream and listening to some music. No stutters or any sort of delay what so ever, everything was smooth. Everything loaded quickly, background taskers were still responsive and demanding software runs smooth as silk. This kind of CPU performance is beneficial for gamers, as this core power makes sure your games never lag even with other programs running in the background. This computer will handle anything you throw at it. 

For any gaming computer, the graphics card is going to maximize the experience, and the NVIDIA GeForce RTX series in the G18 is a powerhouse. These are some of the fastest mobile GPUs available, and they effectively revolutionized the gaming laptop. I tested the G18 with the RTX 4080 model, and the performance was spectacular! Again the FPS's ran smoothly on the ultra settings and it was better than anything else I have owed or tested to date on a laptop.

If you prioritize frame rate, this GPU is for you. In the FPS games I tested, I was consistently pushing frame rates well over 200 FPS on the high settings, allowing me to enjoy that crisp 240Hz display. That smoothness can give you a competitive edge over others especially in the fast-moving FPS games where fractions of a second mean a lot. The RTX 40-series also supports something called hardware-accelerated ray tracing. This brings a more realistic look to the shadows, reflections and lighting. 

So for a machine running this hard all the time, ASUS apparently understood it needed any equally high performing cooling system. So they utilize a three-fan cooling system with Conductonaut Extreme liquid metal on the CPU. This set up allows the ROG Strix G18 to run cool under the stress load.  I stress-tested the system with long gaming sessions, and I was surprised at how well it held up. Even after several hours of playing Starfield on ultra settings, the chassis remained comfortable to the touch and the system didn’t throttle performance due to overheating.

For gamers, when a system gets too hot, it can affect the performance of your CPU or GPU to protect the hardware, which leads to lag and frame rate drops. With this advanced cooling system, the G18 delivers even performance when you are playing extended gaming sessions. The fans tend to kick in when needed, but they are extremely quiet and of zero distraction. ASUS also allows you to adjust performance and fan profiles using "Armoury Crate," so you can go full send with the fans when you are gaming harder, or you can limit the fan use when you are doing lighter work. 
This laptop features a rather large 18" display. The QHD+ (2560x1600) Nebula display with a 240Hz refresh rate. That combo is perfect for anything from competitive gaming to watching a movie. The high resolution provides sharper images as you would expect. What I also learned was that it allows you to use more of your screen than when you compare it to the standard 1080p, Of course the high refresh rate ensures smooth motion while viewing or playing. 

The color is another big plus. The panel supports 100% DCI-P3 color, making colors appear to me as more accurate. Blacks and shadows are deep and rich, and the highlights really stand out. When playing competitively, the combo of high frame rates and low latency creates a super responsive experience that can help improve gameplay. 

The ROG Strix G18 is a large and heavy laptop, but that is because it is loaded with high end components. It has sharp lines highlighted by lighting. The thing just feels substantial and durable, like you would expect a really gaming machine to be. The keyboard is comfortable with a substantially deep press and the keys light up in a manner that does not affect your visibility of the keys with a nice key response.

There are plenty of port options on the G18, with multiple USB-A and USB-C ports, HDMI 2.1, Ethernet, and a full-sized SD card slot. Again, another reason this laptop would be great for gamers and creators. The touchpad is large, and the large chassis leaves enough room for quality speakers that sound excellent.  This is not something that is designed to carry with you all the time, so its not exactly portable. But by far, this is the most portable laptop with the closest to desktop level performance that I have tried to date. But it is a bit heavy in that respect. Personally?  I will trade the weight for this level of performance. 

So I spent a lot of time with the G18, and I have to say it impresses me a lot. Gamers demand certain things, and this hits all the marks. The processing performance and excellent choice for a GPU and an extremely smooth and responsive display. You pay for these options for sure, and there are cheaper options out there. But this is definitely an instance where you get what you pay for. Pull the trigger on this one folks, you won't regret it. I HIGHLY recommend this laptop to anyone wanting a superior gaming computer in a more compact form. Or any influencer wanting the ultimate platform to create their content. You will be happy with your decision.

There are plenty of port options on the G18, with multiple USB-A and USB-C ports, HDMI 2.1, Ethernet, and a full-sized SD card slot. Again, another reason this laptop would be great for gamers and creators. The touchpad is large, and the large chassis leaves enough room for quality speakers that sound excellent.  This is not something that is designed to carry with you all the time, so its not exactly portable. But by far, this is the most portable laptop with the closest to desktop level performance that I have tried to date. But it is a bit heavy in that respect. Personally?  I will trade the weight for this level of performance. 

So I spent a lot of time with the G18, and I have to say it impresses me a lot. Gamers demand certain things, and this hits all the marks. The processing performance and excellent choice for a GPU and an extremely smooth and responsive display. You pay for these options for sure, and there are cheaper options out there. But this is definitely an instance where you get what you pay for. Pull the trigger on this one folks, you won't regret it. I HIGHLY recommend this laptop to anyone wanting a superior gaming computer in a more compact form. Or any influencer wanting the ultimate platform to create their content. You will be happy with your decision.

headline: Near Perfect BEAST!!!!
text:
This is not the daily commuter,  student laptop, or just to Netflix and chill.    
This is for the hardcore gamer, developer, video editor, or designer (or all of the above). 
Perfect for those that are tight on space or need to move around. 

I have been around technology a long time, this is one of the most powerful laptops I have ever used.   While not the biggest, it is big compared to most laptops today, but it uses all of that space for good. 

This full 18" monitor is GORGEOUS, detailed color, bright, just enough bezel to allow your eyes to stay focused on the screen for what ever you are doing.   

Sturdy and firm casing, you can feel it... this isn't flimsy, doesn't dip or tilt like some other large screen mobile devices.   

Full sized keyboard with number keypad... Great for a long list of reasons, a lot of laptops get rid of it... it's here and present. 

My first dislike, is the big oversized touchpad.    I am not a fan of touchpads, especially large ones, that then take a lot of space at the bottom of the deck.    Being a touch typist, for almost 40 years, it is a little awkward, but not crazy bad. There is just a lot of space.. .Bling it up with stickers :) 

RJ-45 hard line port, HDMI, and your standard USB assortment of ports.   

Now for my next negative... Power. 
The power brick is BIG!!! and heavy.  I get it, this big computer needs the power. 
However, it has a custom power connector to the computer on the side.   First would have loved it in the back, as the firm cord, jets out further to the left side, and then with its custom port.. can't readily get a replacement.     Seems to be compatible with USB-C charging, but haven't tried pushing it. 

Thunderbolt ports are going to be really nice, to connect to large monitors.   Only tried a single basic connection, worked great, was able to handle my wide screen, with no decline in image performance.    

It runs Windows out of the box, not going to review Windows, there are thousands of reviews out there.    However, I will say that it took about 2 hours to get it all setup, software and hardware updates, and ready to go.   

Once setup though, here comes the performance. 

From a gaming point of view, I put it through the most recent Forza, and connected a XBOX controller to play.     Racing and graphics was super smooth.  The 5080 graphic card, did its job.    The computer though didn't even seem like it was pushing itself.    Fans were minimal.    And the game play was great.   no issues at all. 

From a design point of view, I fired up Adobe Suite, and was able to do my normal Illustrator usage and editing.  The big screen was great, and I was able to send it over to my CNC machine and do its work.    I don't do a lot of video editing, but did try it out, and full size videos were playing with no hiccups.  Rendering some quick edits were fast, very little lag.     Uploads to YouTube were quick on my WiFi, that clocked at over 600mps, but I was far from my WiFi7 access point, so this was on WiFi6. 

Lastly I fired up Visual Studio, to do some sample compiles, and it was great. 
I typically code on my Mac, but now with this, I will be able to use this Unreal or Unity development, as my Mac is tapping out on that. 


This is going to be a laptop I can use for a long time. 
Outstanding piece of equipment, looking forward to more title releases in 2025 and 2026, that can tap into all its power. 

So to recap:  This really gets a 4.25 out of 5: 
Pros: 
- Big storage 
- Big Memory 
- Big Screen 
- Big Speed 
- Big Performance 

Con's 
- Custom and Large Power Brick 
- Big TouchPad and Big "deck" area

headline: What a beast of a gaming laptop
text:
The ASUS - ROG Strix G18 18" 2.5K 240Hz Gaming Laptop - Intel Core Ultra 9 HX - 32GB RAM - NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 - 2TB SSD - Eclipse Gray is one beast of a laptop!

This ROG Strix G18 laptop comes well packaged as it should as the ROG Strix G18 is a heavy laptop indeed at just over 7lbs, as it needs to be with its stunning 18" WQXGA and all the heat sink's inside to cool the system while in demand like playing games. 

The power supply brick that comes with the ROG Strix G18 is huge as it needs to be, especially plugged in during gameplay, that is required as this Asus laptop need the power to get you the best you can be visually and without lag.   The setup went extremely easy and quick.  The ROG Strix G18 comes with 3 months of pc game pass.  

The display is just a tad below OLED,  meaning  blacks are near perfect black.  Colors are stunning, watching movies are stunning with perfect visuals.  Playing games is just outstanding visually, also just perfect motion at playing games at 240htz.  The display is perfect at everything and stunning! 
Pictures look stunning, movies look stunning, games look stunning.  Viewing angles are great also.  I just love having an 18" high end display built in, basically no need for anything bigger.

The sound this laptop produces is stunning for a laptop, certainly not high end sound system type (as expected) but certainly surprised on how great the speakers sound.

Wifi 7 works great, super fast connection and definitely delivers on minimal lag in games, just like playing while plugged into Ethernet.

The keyboard is just wow, you can set the color of your choice as the backlight.  The keys feel great and placement of the keys is perfect. I love having a number pad.

Playing games on the ROG Strix G18 is just wow, the NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5080 with the Intel Core Ultra 9 HX processor, this combo has so much power for present and future games.   Playing games on this without any lag is just mind blowing.  The response of the entire laptop and hearing the fans kick up when the 16 gigabytes of GPU ram of GDDR7 is used and you see and feel it while playing games, nice and smoothly as it should be.  Asus just got everything perfect in syncing everything perfectly.  You can max out all visualls in games and this Asus laptop just handles all aspects perfectly.  I saw absolutely no studder, jitter or game lag.

I was blown away at what games look like when you have all the power you need to get you to a point and beyond of stunning visuals and extremely smooth gameplay, that is extremely greatfull, so you have that advantage over others!

You will not be disappointed! 
I am just blown away by this laptop!

headline: Laptop gaming beast!
text:
This laptop is a beast in the best possible way. Yes, it’s fairly expensive, but you get a beautiful, high-performance, portable gaming machine. In a nutshell, it runs cool, the fans are not too noisy, the graphics performance is top-notch, and the 18” monitor is beautiful. It is a little on the heavy side (a bit more than 7lbs) but it’s perfectly fine to haul to those occasional game nights with friends. 
At home, I typically use it with a Samsung 49” Odyssey Neo which it handles perfectly. My old gaming laptop would have some annoying stutter at times during lots of screen movement, but so far, the ASUS has been butter smooth for me. But if you don’t have or want to mess with an external monitor, the 18” monitor on the laptop is perfectly fine.
It was easy to get set up initially. After the Windows updates were done, I started installing games via Microsoft Xbox. There are some useful ASUS utilities for system performance, graphics, etc. but very little in the way of annoying bloatware like on some computers these days. The 2TB drive gives me plenty of room, so I’m not worried about having to expand any time soon. 
You can read all the specs and other details of the system, so I won’t go into that, but here are some features I like. The RGB lightbar that outlines the underneath side of the laptop is a nice touch. It’s not something that would have influenced my purchasing decision, but now that I have it, I really like it. The chamfered edges of the laptop are a nice touch, too, and it makes the laptop seem a little sleeker. 
My favorite feature, though, is the tool-less access to the RAM, SSD, and fans on the back. I don’t know why every system made from now on would NOT have this kind of simple access. Not that I’m going to be messing with the RAM and SSD all the time, but it will be nice to be able to make sure the fans are staying clean. I do have cats that like to lay around near the computers, so this is going to be great for keeping the air flow clean.
Speaking of the fans and airflow, another nice design feature is the hot air is vented out the back and not to the sides. So many laptops over the years would blow hot air out the side right onto your mouse hand, which I found annoying. With this laptop, the intakes are on the side and the vents are on the rear. 
One small detail that would have been nice is a power connector that was a 90-degree elbow instead of straight out. The power cord does stick out quite a way on the left side and my only concern is about bumping it or possibly smashing it into something. If it had a 90-degree turn, then it would be a sleeker fit and could route towards the back. Having said that, when I’m using it with an HDMI cable plugged in, then they’re both sticking out about the same, so it doesn’t matter as much.
Overall, I’m super impressed with gaming on this computer. I feel like it’s top-of-the-line enough that it’s going to continue running my games for years to come.  If this type of machine is within your budget, I think you’ll be very happy with the ASUS ROG Strix G18.

computers these days the 2tb drive gives me plenty of room so i m not worried about having to expand any time soon you can read all the specs and other details of the system so i won t go into that but here are some features i like the rgb lightbar that outlines the underneath side of the laptop is a nice touch it s not something that would have influenced my purchasing decision but now that i have it i really like it the chamfered edges of the laptop are a nice touch too and it makes the laptop seem a little sleeker my favorite feature though is the tool less access to the ram ssd and fans on the back i don t know why every system made from now on would not have this kind of simple access not that i m going to be messing with the ram and ssd all the time but it will be nice to be able to make sure the fans are staying clean i do have cats that like to lay around near the computers so this is going to be great for keeping the air flow clean speaking of the fans and airflow another nice design feature is the hot air is vented out the back and not to the sides so many laptops over the years would blow hot air out the side right onto your mouse hand which i found annoying with this laptop the intakes are on the side and the vents are on the rear one small detail that would have been nice is a power connector that was a 90 degree elbow instead of straight out the power cord does stick out quite a way on the left side and my only concern is about bumping it or possibly smashing it into something if it had a 90 degree turn then it would be a sleeker fit and could route towards the back having said that when i m using it with an hdmi cable plugged in then they re both sticking out about the same so it doesn t matter as much overall i m super impressed with gaming on this computer i feel like it s top of the line enough that it s going to continue running my games for years to come if this type of machine is within your budget i think you ll be very happy with the asus rog strix g18

headline: What a machine!
text:
WOW.  I wish I could write this review and just leave it there.  I have had other high end gaming laptops in the past but never have I been this blown away by the performance, versatility, look, and feel of one of these machines.

First off, the unboxing and packaging.  The box that this unit arrived in was just a cool presentation as it lifted the laptop up slightly when opened giving the vibe of premium right out of the gate.  Not much included in the box, small instruction and warranty paperwork, the charger, and the laptop itself and you're set.

The physical feel of this machine just screams premium.  The materials feel nice and at 18" on the screen it's large.  I do not intend to do much travelling with this and rather mostly treat it like a desktop that takes up way less space, but if you did want to travel with it, you need a large and sturdy bag.  The keyboard is of course RGB backlit and there is even lighting around the bottom to give it that "gamer" look.

Booting up, setting up, etc was very quick.  It's very fast, but standard windows setup.  Immediately moved into downloading some games from the Xbox PC app (I have Gamepass, highly recommend) and getting Steam going.  I've tried a few things from indie titles that are not very intense up to the latest releases and some free to play titles.  Everything I have tried has run very smoothly and looked very impressive whether I used the built in monitor or hooked up to my normal docking station.  Speaking of docking, The setup to connect to my triple monitor, gaming keyboard and mouse, external webcam and mic docking station was absolutely seamless.  I've even done a bit of twitch streaming on this system and had no issues.

Overall, this unit carries an premium price tag and it delivers.  As the PC gaming industry trends more towards portability and ease of use with products like this as well as handheld options like the Steamdeck and upcoming Xbox branded ROG Ally, this premium price point delivers on everything I can think of or could want from a high end gaming laptop.  If it's in your budget, this is the one to get.

headline: Multiple buying attempts, all freezing issues
text:
I have attempted to purchase 3 of these ROG Strix 18" laptops since February. Every single one of them had freezing issues.

I am a system builder, and I know my way around Windows, drivers, updates, SSDs,  ect. I know Asus machines very well. My 5 year old gaming Asus ROG machine is still running to this day.

I don't know WHAT is going on with these machines, but they are NOT ready for release. The first one I bought had faulty wiring in it, and the backlit keyboard would not work. The second and third ones worked fine for a couple of days, and then started freezing. No Blue Screen of Death. Straight up, freezing. Everything would just lock up. No mouse movements, no keyboard response, nothing. I needed to hold down the power button for a hard reset. Afterward, it would boot up normally, and moments after it would totally freeze again. The LED light next to the charging port would just rapidly flash a while color.

I had all the latest Windows Updates, I had all the latest BIOS and drivers from the My Asus app. This happened on 2 machines in the span of 3 days.

These are not ready for release, and with the amount of software and licenses I have to assign to my machines and what not, this is unacceptable. At this price point, these things should be 1000% flawless right out of the box.

I will not buy another Asus laptop again. This has been by fat the worse computer experience I have ever had. And I am a 25 year system builder. It's a shame, because specs wise these are impressive. Nothing but issues with them.

It very well could be BIOS or driver update related. Some of us are trying to run businesses with these machines, and  we just don't have time to deal with this garbage.

headline: UFO-Orochi: The Ultimate Gaming/Workstation Beast - Exceeded
text: Just received my Alienware 18 Area-51 and I'm absolutely blown away! This machine is everything I hoped for and more. The RTX 5080 + Intel Ultra 9 275HX combo is incredible. Everything runs buttery smooth, from AAA games to AI model training for my Master's in AI. The 64GB RAM handles massive multitasking without breaking a sweat. The CherryMX mechanical keyboard is a game-changer - perfect tactile feedback for both gaming and long coding sessions. The 18" display at 300Hz is gorgeous and massive - perfect for productivity and gaming. The Liquid Teal color and AlienFX lighting look absolutely stunning. The Cryo-Chamber cooling keeps everything running cool and quiet even under heavy loads. Perfect for: AI/ML professionals, content creators, serious gamers, anyone who needs desktop-replacement power.

headline: Alienware 18 - Area 51 Great Features
text: After buying Dell laptops for 30+ years, I can say they are well made and, if you have a problem, Dell will make it right. The Alienware 18 Area 51 laptop I bought was priced right and has great features. The extra cost Cherry Keyboard is well worth it and should be standard. The positive clicky feeling is the way mechanical keyboards should operate. Unfortunately, the laptop they sent me had a problem with the WIFI 7 adapter. It worked on WIFI 6 but had issues with WIFI 7. Dell tech support is always there, and they tried to assist, but hardware issues require replacement. This laptop has the WIFI adapter soldered to the motherboard, which prevents an easy fix. As far as I'm concerned, this is a design flaw. WIFI cards should be user replaceable and upgradable. Dell learned the hard way as I returned this laptop for a refund and purchased another brand with a user replaceable WIFI 7 card. But I say with confidence that my other Dell laptops have been extremely dependable and rugged so you can't go wrong with a Dell laptop.

The positive clicky feeling is the way mechanical keyboards should operate. Unfortunately, the laptop they sent me had a problem with the WIFI 7 adapter. It worked on WIFI 6 but had issues with WIFI 7. Dell tech support is always there, and they tried to assist, but hardware issues require replacement. This laptop has the WIFI adapter soldered to the motherboard, which prevents an easy fix. As far as I'm concerned, this is a design flaw. WIFI cards should be user replaceable and upgradable. Dell learned the hard way as I returned this laptop for a refund and purchased another brand with a user replaceable WIFI 7 card. But I say with confidence that my other Dell laptops have been extremely dependable and rugged so you can't go wrong with a Dell laptop.

headline: It's a Beast
text: Overall, the system is a beast. I have yet to find its upper end except on AI development (hint: there is no upper end). Eats games for breakfast. Cooling is more than adequate, although I do use a cooling pad with fans. Congrats to your engineers. Now we'll see if it lasts 5 years... I do have two wishes: 1) Laptop engineers seem to think that keeping a standard keyboard will put them out of a job. Create a little app that, when you press a key (How DF do you use the M1 key?) it gives you all the info you need. You can skip letters, thank you. 2) Have a simple, direct way to set the battery to 80% max charge. Phones do it, tablets do it, you're way late and it's not a hard job for your lovely engineers.

headline: Alienware 18 Area 51 Gaming Laptop
text: I got the intel 9 ultra with 5090 64gb ram 2TB ssd model and it blows my Alienware Aurora R14 desktop 3080 with Ryzen 5 5500 32gb ram out of the water. Can't believe how powerful this thing is after reading the laptop GPUs are roughly 30% weaker than desktop GPUs. Maybe it is compared to a desktop 5090 but even running the most intensive games this thing doesn't even sweat. It's heavy as expected but otherwise it's pretty quiet, runs great, and love the 300hz monitor slightly better quality than my 240hz 1080p desktop monitors. Ended up getting it for around 3k which is what I paid for my R14 almost 5-6 years ago now.

headline: New laptop
text: Having been an Alienware customer since the very beginning, (this is my 5th now) I miss some of the uniqueness that Alienware was known for. I also wish some of the new product launch's had more customization options in terms of hardware (ie hard drive choices). IMHO marketing a laptop that offers up to 3 drives but only offering mostly single drive options is rather limiting from a gaming brand.

headline: Had to replace a perfectly good computer AGAIN
text: For the second time in the last 15 years had to replace a perfectly good computer because monopoly Microsoft is stopping support of the operating system. I went with the closest to the original, a 17 Alienware, I could get, an 18 Area-51 Alienware laptop. Compared to the other this is turbo charged and hope it lasts a long time. Windows 11, culprit responsible for the upgrade, is pushy with AI wanting to butt in everywhere, and OneDrive took my photographs and documents hostage until I figured out how to stop it.

headline: She's a Beauty
text: As I'm retired, this was purchased to be primarily for gaming and I couldn't be more happy. I jumped from the 3000 gen to the 5000 gen (and a 5090 at that) and am quite impressed by the improvements over that time. I've yet to have heating issues, so it would seem any and all gaming a go. I'm sure this laptop will last me many years to come and the unique teal color is just icing on the cake. Now if Dell would just fix the Dell Support Assist software it would be a grand slam!

headline: All it's cracked up to be.
text: Cons: It's huge, and the cord isn't very long nor the battery life great, thus, not a great curl up on the couch and write laptop, but I have an aging lightweight dell that still works fine as a basic word processor, and I had zero expectations for a gaming laptop to have a good battery life. It can get toasty, but no more than other gaming laptops, and you definitely do not need any external cooling fans or anything. It's a little slow on startup and doesn't recognize my USB mouse right away, but that's trivial compared to the pros. Fingerprints easily show up on the pretty casing. Hate the huge copilot key, which could have been made miniscule so the home and end keys could be more conveniently located. FYI: I ordered mostly top specs as far as 5090 and 64 gig ram. Only did the 2TB gen4 SSD as I'd hit (ahem, exceeded) my budget max already, but it might have been worth the bigger and gen5 SSD to better future proof, maybe, maybe not. Pros: It's very pretty. Flawlessly runs KCD2, BG3, and heavily modded skyrim, all at max graphics, and is very pretty and fluid on the attached screen or when hooked up to 65 inch TV. I don't game online so I can't say how it performs, but the download speeds over wifi are impressive, so I suspect that wouldnt be a problem. Overall a huge upgrade from my prior PCs, such as my aging Alienware desktop and my prior 4060 laptop, which could run the above mentioned games at medium graphics yet still lagged. Easily runs other apps like photoshop, of course. Overall: Highly recommend. I'm thrilled with it, glad I upgraded, and think this will get a lot of miles out of it.

headline: A Gamer's Dream: Alienware 18" Area-51 laptop
text: My Alienware 18" Area-51 Gaming Laptop is transformative. It's a powerhouse, a visual marvel, and a testament to Alienware's commitment to top-tier gaming. From unboxing, its premium feel, "Liquid Teal" finish, and robust magnesium alloy chassis impressed. The mesmerizing Alienware RGB lighting enhances the gaming atmosphere. The 18-inch WQXGA (2560 x 1600) 300Hz/3ms display is breathtaking. Games are stunningly clear, vibrant, and unbelievably smooth, making every frame alive. Under the hood, my Intel Core Ultra 9 275HX and NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5090 configuration handles everything with ease. I upgraded to 64GB of DDR5 RAM and a blazing-fast 2TB NVMe M.2 PCIe Gen5 SSD, ensuring lightning-quick load times. AAA titles run at max settings with incredible frame rates, rivaling desktop setups. The cooling system is a triumph. Even during intense sessions, the laptop remains remarkably cool, preventing thermal throttling. The fans are a pleasant "whoosh" and unnoticeable with a headset. The Cherry MX mechanical keyboard offers tactile feedback and comfortable, responsive typing. Per-key AlienFX RGB lighting adds personalization. Though large, its portability for a machine of this caliber is impressive, perfect for LAN parties. The array of ports, including Thunderbolt 5, is convenient. In conclusion, the Alienware 18" Area-51 is an absolute triumph. It's a no-compromise gaming machine delivering an unparalleled experience. For serious gamers seeking the best in mobile performance, stunning visuals, and a premium build, this is an investment in pure gaming bliss. Highly, highly recommended!

headline: Real quality in laptop thermal design.
text: I tried about 3 other 5000 series laptops before picking the Alienware 18 inch with a 5090 in it, I have to say I am not disappointed. I have never seen thermals so good in a laptop, ever and I've managed two computer stores repairing laptops in the past. It draws in air from the top! Why have I never seen this in a laptop before, the fans aren't loud and even while benchmarking it does not thermal throttle, I get temps on the 5090 in the 60 most of the time while playing, sometime 71 max and 70 for the CPU.. this exact config on the HP omen max hit 105c after one minute of benchmarking. Screen is not OLED but it's still a great screen probably best I've seen on an IPS display, build quality is solid and nice, the typing experience with the cherry mx keys is awesome I get a great score on monkey type, similar to my ergo desktop keyboard score. This is a beast the only thing I would warn you is it's HUGE and heavy but the 16 inch variant does not perform as well as this one, if you are considering one versus the other get the 18 and go big you won't regret it. If you travel a lot and want something easy to take with you look elsewhere altogether but if you want a real desktop replacement that won't burn itself up in a year get this bad boy

headline: Awesome Laptop
text: The visual display is sharp and life-like, with accurate color representation. The Core i9 processor is extremely fast and responsive. The 64 GB of DDR5 RAM contributes to fast processing and response to commands. The 18" Display is an excellent size for detailed and complex work with spreadsheets, Visio diagrams, and graphic designs. The 2 TB SSD is great for mass storage on the laptop, and the SD Card slot allows removable storage of large files for portable use. The keyboard and touchpad are comfortable and responsive. This gaming laptop is great for business power users as well as gamers.

headline: nice and high quality exterior
text: thunderbolt 5 does not exist on this laptop at all. the USBC is more like usb3.2 30w but the ports are split in 2 and given the USB4 driver 4k60hz is a maximum per port on this pc as a result of false advertisement timespy gives a nice 22k score. R24 2000 score USB charging is either not currently supported or i do not have a device capable of the minimum 96w to charge as stated by the Manuel(or because thunderbolt is just missing completely) everything else about the laptop even down to the thermals are correct. as for drivers(dell rhymes with h&ll) its not normal compared to a desktop driver install. genuine windows 11 is safe to install but the drivers require installing in a certain order to not go corrupt. hybrid graphics seems to use more power then dedicated graphics by about 30w even for idle cases. i have this system down to 50w.(hybrid was 80w)

headline: Absolutely gorgeous machine
text: The cooling solution (the cryochamber) in this beauty is absolutely doing a spectacular job. Solid 10/5! I don't recall ever seeing a high end gaming laptop with cooling this good! (From Alienware or otherwise). The Intel Ultra Core 275hx and the RTX 5080 actually go to their advertised speeds of 160W and 175W respectively with a combined power up to 280W under constant load favouring the GPU or CPU based on the power/thermal profile used. With 4 speakers (2 woofers and 2 tweeters) you can probably hold a party with this machine! (The speakers are that load yes!) 2 SODIMM slots with memory up to 6400MT/s + 3 Nvme Gen 5 Slots + 2 Thunderbolt 5 slots + 5Gbit Ethernet, Full size SD card, regular Type A usb 3 ports, I couldn't ask for more (perhaps a mini-displayport port would have been nice, but we get a full HDMI 2.1 port - not the mini version of it, so no complaints there). I love the Liquid Teal colour. It reminds me of Alienware of old! Only gripe is that the screen is IPS and not OLED, but I don't want glossy OLED, I would have liked a matte OLED screen (Valve was able to do it for the Steam Deck OLED, so maybe next time Alienware can do it as well ^_^). However, the IPS at 500+ nits and 100% DCIP-3 accuracy is one of the best IPS panels I have ever experienced and it's matte, which is a MAJOR WIN! It is "thin" at least compared to the previous Alienware Area-51m R2 (or R1) and it is a desktop replacement, but with just one power-brick this time instead of two (thank God!) My only recommendation is to grab the 18' backpack! I was absolutely impressed with the quality! And funny enough, even if the laptop is quite heavy at around 5kg with the adapter, it is very comfortable to travel with (Previously I have used my Vindicator 17' backpack with my 17x laptop and Area-51m R1/R2 laptops. I will let you with a few shots of the laptop and how it looks compared with the previous Area-51m R1 :)

headline: Powerhouse - Buy it! No regrets.
text: I have upgraded from a 15" 4070 to this 18" 5080. Handling 4K resolution at max graphics better then i expected. Black Myth Wukong sits between 30-45FPS. I'm currently playing Kingdom Come Deliverance 2 on "experimental" settings and not noticing any problems with frame rate at 2560 x 1600 Be wary of the surface you put the laptop onto. The bottom can get scratched if you put it on a rugged surface. I left mine on a metal mouse mat and the edges of the mouse mat caught it and caused some scuff marks. Its heavy, but comfortable on the lap. It does get toasty, not uncomfortable at all but you do start to sweat. I would recommend you find an appropriate tray to keep you cool. My previous 4070 laptop would regularly run at 90+ degrees and you couldn't touch the laptop for long without burning yourself. I haven't had that experience here. If you were unsure about the mechanical keyboard, just do it! If you're a touch typist like myself, you won't notice you're using an American layout keyboard. Its well worth the money and has made typing on this machine so much nicer.

headline: Upgraded from a 4070 to a 5080, amazing!
text: I've had the laptop for a few days and have run a few benchmarks on recent games I want to play. I'm happy with the performance sitting around 45 FPS for Black Myth Wukong at 4K maxed out settings, realistically you won't want to have everything maxed, so dial it down and have a consistent 60FPS. The wrist rest is very comfortable. The 18" screen fills your field of view and doesn't feel small. The laptop is heavy, charger is small. Mechanical keyboard feels and sounds great.

headline: Alienware 18 Area-51 for industrial field service
text: Cross-shopped this laptop with Dell business class laptops and Panasonic offerings for rough business use. When you add extended service contract costs and compare features, Alienware is competitive despite high purchase cost. I operate in the desert southwest. When I am forced to work outside in 100+ °F and direct sunlight, the screen affords a wider viewing angle like no others, and the advanced cooling system design helps a lot. Indoors, the cooling system is relevant in industrial hot zones. This system with the power brick is over 12 lbs, but I always pack a lot more than that to a job site.

headline: Amazing Laptop with one flaw.
text: Needed a new gaming laptop & after A LOT of research settled on this Alienware 18 Area51. Easy to spec on website & easy checkout. Kept well informed by email & text during ordering & building. Laptop arrived TWO WEEKS later well packaged. Looks stunning & very well built. Hasn't miss a beat with gaming & keeps cool throughout. Be Aware: Dell's global courier (DP World) are appalling. Tracking was useless. No facility to upgrade to better courier on Dell's website! Lets down the purchase.

headline: Very Solid Laptop (So Far)
text: I've really been enjoying this laptop so far. The performance is great, and the laptop stays pretty cool even while I'm playing demanding games like Battlefield 6 or Alan Wake 2. I also love the keyboard, it's significantly better than the keyboard on my old Lenovo Legion laptop. My only real (but still fairly minor) complaint is with the screen, the resolution is fine but the dynamic range is definitely lacking. Not enough to really bother me, but I was hoping for a little more for Alienware's highest end laptop. Overall very happy, and if in a few years Alienware announces a new version of this laptop with an improved screen I could definitely see myself upgrading!

headline: Great, with blemishes
text: Overall, awesome laptop. The performance has exceeded my expectations. The build quality is top notch. Issues I've found: The screen backlight is very noticeable in blacks. The material used for the case is a grease magnet and easily scratched. The laptop would randomly crash / close out of some games. The Alienware command center app is not user friendly. Happy with the product, but for the price I wanted it to run flawlessly. I can live with the screen, but not the random performance.

headline: Shipped damaged
text: This is the fourth Alienware laptop I have bought for gaming while driving a truck all across the country. This laptop runs great and does what I wanted from it. My only complaint is it was shipped with cosmetic damage. From the photo below you can see the inner box it was packaged in was clearly damaged but it was shipped anyway. The actual damage is basically cosmetic and I didn't raise any issues due to not wanting to deal with the delay of returning the product for replacement.

headline: It's a great laptop for gaming and other activities
text: When I ordered this Area-51 18 inch laptop I thought it would come with the fan and touch pad LEDs. When it arrived and did not have them I had to look deeper at the description to see that those only came with certain graphic card systems. The laptop pictures on the Dell website showed those additional LEDs, but it wasn't clear in the description that those were only on certain models. I was disappointed when the laptop arrived and those weren't on it. I would have ordered a different system with those included had it been made more apparent on the site. I'm not unhappy with the laptop, just disappointed that the LEDs are not a part of it.

headline: Alienware m18 with RTX 5090 – Powerhouse or Price Trap?
text: The Alienware m18 is an impressive laptop — no doubt. It's ideal for creators and professionals who need strong mobile performance, or gamers who want desktop-like power in one portable machine. But make no mistake: this is not true 5090 performance. For the same money, a desktop would give you 30–40% more raw power. If mobility matters, and money is no issue, this is one of the best laptops you can buy. If you're expecting a true desktop replacement? You'll be left a bit underwhelmed. Rating: 4.1/5 Premium, portable, powerful — but not a full desktop killer.

headline: Out of This World Awesome
text: Due to my newly acquired nomadic lifestyle, I desperately needed a portable desktop. CES came along and I waited for all major brands to release their top teir offerings. Every single one did not have the build quality, features, and specs in the same pricepoint other than the Alienware. The team behind this product not only knocked it out of the park, but out of this world! Although, my unit did arrive with a tiny scratch at the top cover, the laptop performs above and beyond my expectations.

headline: Powerhouse with minor problems.
text: Computer works great for VR. Gaming wise, Nvidia is still fixing the drivers. Apparently there's a problem where having alot of extra vram makes some games act weird. I was seriously disappointed my favorite game crashes immediately so I can't play it ever again; I think it has to do with Nvidia dropping physics support in the new graphics cards. Also the alienware command center is broke AF. Beyond trying to reinstall, it's hit or miss that it'll work. I expect most of the software bugs to be fixed with time so I'd consider them minor flaws. I think for the price point, the reliability of dell, and quality/performance I would recommend this over every other gaming laptop.

headline: Powerful specs inside stylish laptop let down down by screen
text: I got this laptop to replace my 8 year old XPS. I wasn't keen on Dell's new design of the XPS and wanted something that could house the latest generation of Nvidia GPU's. The Area 51 (18inch) ticked all the boxes - the chassis is well designed and looks very stylish indeed. So far I am very impressed with it and its thermal control when playing games appears to be very good for a laptop. I was left disappointed by the screen quality however. I had to return my first delivery as there was clearly a dead pixel (or a few) in the corner of the screen. I didn't notice any backlight bleed (BLB), but I only had the laptop on for a short time and had used it in a bright room. There are no dead pixels on the second one I ordered and kept, but the backlight bleeding and ips glow is noticeable when the screen is showing dark colours or if I'm not sat in a bright room. Reducing the brightness does help, but it's clear to see if I haven't got a light on. I understand that BLB and IPS glow are to be expected to some degree with this type of screen, but I would say the extent I have with my Area 51 laptop is the worst I've ever seen on an IPS screen and just barely acceptable for product in this price range. It's a shame really when everything else is so good. Perhaps I'm expecting too much from the technology, but when your paying several thousand for a laptop it should look and feel premium all over. Outside of dark colours, the screen does indeed look very good with no noticeable blemishes. I prefer to have an IPS screen for a laptop that's going to be used for games and music production/performance (over say an OLED which would cost a lot more and has it's own issues). I am happy enough with my purchase and hope this laptop will last as long as the last one I owned (the XPS felt flawless and was half the price). I just wonder if Dell could've done a better job ensuring the quality of the screen was on a par with the rest of the laptop prior to shipping. I would recommend it to someone who's prime consideration is having a portible, powerful machine with a well designed chassis for keeping all that tech cool. For anyone after superb visual fidelity without compromise on a laptop screen, look elsewhere.

If you do anything slightly heavier than that then do rely one battery.

headline: Arrived Late, Damaged, Overheats, Support is AI Generated
text: My first experience with Dell was not positive. I'm used to building my own PCs and buying second hand laptops, and I figured I'd finally try Alienware since I've heard such great things about it almost 20 years ago. It's clear Alienware no longer lives up to its past reputation and has fallen from grace. - Laptop arrived late. Almost 2 months in, and I still don't have a working product I paid for. - Dell initially refused to honor their price match guarantee. - Laptop runs hot sitting in desktop only (25-35% persistent CPU usage, no apps, after win update + reboot). - Laptop CPU sits at 100% with just Firefox on Google home page. - Laptop arrived damage, vent was ruined during assembly. - Dell's support was almost entirely AI generated. I agreed to a refund to end this ordeal. I will not be buying from Dell again.

headline: Upgrade Blows My Desktop Away
text:
I purchased this laptop to replace my desktop that couldn’t upgrade to windows 11. The performance of this machine is absolutely night and day. I game, stream, and edit videos as some of my heavier tasks and my desktop was able to run these programs okay. They had to be on the lowest settings possible to run smoothly. With this laptop, everything is running on Highest settings and flawlessly at that. My biggest games are Overwatch 2, Anno 1800, and Hoyoverse titles. After some adjustments in the system settings (making sure the games were running on the dGPU instead of hybrid, etc) every title is running perfectly. You can set up and be playing in minutes. The OLED display is beautiful. It’s capable of HDR but I honestly prefer the OLED for gaming. It has a decent battery life. I don’t game while unplugged but while I’m unplugged just browsing or using discord, it lasts plenty long enough for me. I have not fully tested this yet however. 

I was upgrading from a GTX 1060, and I can tell the difference drastically. In FPS games, suddenly it makes sense how other people could use snipers and I couldn’t. The frames are just that much smoother, that much easier to work with. I was nervous to drop this kind of money on a laptop with how much gripe they get, but I have zero regrets. This thing is better than my desktop ever was, even 6 years ago. I have yet to run into an issue it can’t handle. It’s lighter than I thought it’d be too. Maybe slightly heavier than my old MacBook Pro? But not enough to be noticeable by any means. I am very pleased with this purchase and if you’re also on the fence about a laptop in this price range, I say go for it.

headline: Great Performance and Build Quality
text: This Lenovo Legion 7i is excellent. The build feels premium, the screen is bright and very smooth, and the performance is outstanding for gaming and multitasking. Games run fast with no stuttering, and the laptop stays reasonably cool for how powerful it is. The fans can get loud and the battery isn’t the best, but that’s normal for a gaming laptop. Overall, great value and highly recommended.

headline: Lenovo Legion 7i Intel Core Ulta 9 275 HX, 32 GB M
text:
I'm a huge Lenovo fan, and I absolutely fell in love with this computer aesthetically, and I'd never seen such a great screen. It's my first high-end computer. I had to seek some advice on the BIOS and driver, but Lenovo itself has very good guides inside the computer.
For gaming, I imagine it's normal for it to get hot like any computer. I had the previous version, and it got so hot it shut off on its own that I returned it under warranty. I spent a little more money and got this beauty.
I haven't had any problems and have enjoyed high performance for gaming. I learned this option when I put it in work mode by simply pressing the fn + R keys, and I thought it was fantastic.
In a few months, I'd like the new one, which has a larger screen with 4K resolution.
This one has up to 2.5K, and I thought it was a beauty.

headline: Perfect for me
text: After looking at several laptops, some with the RTX5070TI or even the 5080 I kept getting called back to this one for some reason. The reason was the appearance, it is sleek and stylish. After getting it home and trying it out for the last month I am in no way disappointed. Games extremely well for me, but I am not a huge gamer so I am not playing demanding games. It gets loud, but not as loud as my previous Alienware with an RTX 2070, and that would also throttle down when gaming and sometimes freeze, this never has. I did remove a few of the installed apps that IO did not care for or would hang the system up, but other than that I truly love it, especially the screen.

headline: Power house!
text:
I couldn’t be happier with my new Lenovo Legion 7i 16” OLED Gaming Laptop! From the moment I turned it on, the speed and clarity blew me away. The Intel Core Ultra 9 and RTX 5070 handle everything I throw at it — from AutoCAD and design software to gaming and video editing — all without breaking a sweat.

The OLED display is absolutely stunning; colors pop with incredible depth and the 2.5K resolution makes every detail shine. The build quality feels premium, the RGB keyboard is smooth and responsive, and even under heavy use, it stays surprisingly cool and quiet.

This laptop has completely elevated my productivity and creativity — it’s perfect for design students, professionals, and gamers alike. If you’re looking for top-tier performance in a beautiful, lightweight package, this is the one.

Highly recommend it — worth every penny!

— Jana Spurloc

headline: Lenovo Legion 7i
text:
The Legion 7i, especially its latest 2025 iteration (Gen 10), ships with cutting-edge specs like the Intel Core Ultra 9 275HX processor paired with NVIDIA RTX 50-series GPUs—up to the RTX 5080—delivering jaw-dropping performance. In benchmarks, it leads the pack. Gaming and visuals come alive on its 16-inch, 240 Hz OLED WQXGA panel—vibrant, color-accurate, and silky-smooth. The Legion 7i combines a sleek, modern aesthetic with smart ergonomics. It garners praise for its clean design and abundant ports—including Thunderbolt 4, USB-C/A, HDMI 2.1, and RJ-45—ideal for gaming setups and creative workflows alike.
Thanks to its advanced cooling system, the CPU can consistently operate at ~150–170 W, even when under load, with temperatures around 85–90 °C and fan noise between 45–46 dBA—impressive for such power.
The Legion 7i’s SteelSeries-based keyboard delivers excellent tactile feedback, quiet typing, and unique features like force-sensing WASD keys and customizable keycaps—ideal for precision gaming.
Minor Trade-Offs
• Pricey & Heavy: The best-in-class hardware comes at a cost, both financially (starting around $2,849) and in portability (nearly 6 lb)
• Battery Life: Like most powerful gaming laptops, it has below-average battery endurance—not ideal for extended unplugged use.
• Thermal Sensitivity: To get peak sustained performance, it's best placed on a stand to improve airflow—the cooling design is very capable, but flat desk usage might push thermal limits.

headline: Great buy!!
text:
I recently purchased the Lenovo Legion laptop, and it has exceeded all of my expectations. The build quality feels premium, and the sleek white design really stands out. Performance-wise, it’s an absolute powerhouse — the NVIDIA RTX graphics combined with the latest processor handle gaming, streaming, and multitasking with ease. The display is crisp and vibrant, and the refresh rate makes everything feel smooth and responsive.

One of my favorite features is the RGB keyboard, which not only looks great but also feels very comfortable to type on during long sessions. Cooling is efficient, so the laptop stays surprisingly quiet even under heavy loads.

Overall, this is one of the best laptops I’ve owned — perfect for gaming, content creation, and productivity. Best Buy’s ordering and pickup process was smooth and hassle-free, too. Highly recommend this machine to anyone looking for power and style in one package.

headline: Best looking laptop
text:
Got one refurbished-excellent on sale for $1380 before tax.

You pay for the build quality, and it’s worth the price.  It’s clean and professional, without any gaming aesthetic.  The display blew me and my girlfriend away even compared to other OLED laptop screens; she’s (jokingly) jealous of how good this thing is and she by no means skimped out on her own gaming laptop.  

I’m impressed by how powerful the 275HX CPU is as well, though it’s a little too powerful for the chassis.  It’s somehow got more computing power than my desktop 13700k at half the wattage; intel arrow lake isn’t impressive as a desktop chip but it’s a big improvement for laptop chips.  My legion 7 will thermal throttle well before the cpu is fully utilized; consider undervolting and frequency limiting or setting a custom fan curve since it’s got cpu horsepower to spare.

The GPU is the weakest point of this laptop; everyone complains the 5070 with 8gb vram is insufficient and it really does struggle with 1440p gaming.  There’s no getting around it; go for something with a 5070 ti or greater if graphics-heavy gaming is important.  Or, like, use a desktop instead.

I sure like how it looks though, and I think its aesthetics and build quality make up for its shortcomings in graphics, thermals and battery life compared to other laptops at a similar price.  At any sale price at $1700 or below I think this thing warrants consideration for anyone who doesn’t use a laptop solely for gaming.  Or who does and doesn’t want to look like they do.

headline: A great laptop? Who knows, it can’t handle wifi.
text:
After a mere few days I had to return this laptop. Why?

Because it couldn’t stay connected to the internet.

You’d think laptops would be able to perform this basic feature. But it was so bad that I barely managed to get through the initial setup! After that, it couldn’t hold a steady connection for more than a minute. 

Worst part is that if you look up “lenovo legion 7i gen 10 can't connect to internet” on Google, you’ll find other folks with the same problem. But who would bother to look up if a *laptop* can connect to the *internet* before buying, in the year 2025? Silly me for thinking that was a given.

2 stars for the nice design, monitor, and the fact that I really couldn’t test the limits of this laptop. Maybe if held a steady connection, I would have loved it.

headline: Great Specs, Broken Customization (Legion Station)
text: I bought this Lenovo Legion and, while it’s a very powerful machine, I’m giving it three stars for a couple of issues. First, it shipped with Windows 11 2024 instead of the 2025 version. Second, the Lenovo “Legion Station” app has a bug that forces the keyboard lighting and dark mode back to default every time I restart, ignoring my saved settings. I contacted both Best Buy and Lenovo; the only ‘solution’ they offered was to return the laptop. Uninstalling the app stopped the resets, but now I can’t customize the keyboard lighting or use certain performance/shortcut modes the software enables. It’s frustrating to have to accept this kind of limitation on a laptop that costs over two thousand dollars.

I contacted both Best Buy and Lenovo; the only ‘solution’ they offered was to return the laptop. Uninstalling the app stopped the resets, but now I can’t customize the keyboard lighting or use certain performance/shortcut modes the software enables. It’s frustrating to have to accept this kind of limitation on a laptop that costs over two thousand dollars.

I got an hp omen max with an rtx 5080 and this just performs so much better than that despite having a 5070 gpu. You would need to do some tweaking in legion space as the CPU temp limits are set to 103 by default. Bring that down and increase the GPU wattage and baam you now have a thin, light extremely good gaming laptop with pretty much all games running smooth like butter. Overall very happy with this purchase and that HP Omen Max is going to the returns list

headline: Powerful and high-quality, although with temperatu
text: The laptop is fine, it is good for gaming, the quality of the materials is very good, the screen is perfect, the only thing that didn't seem right to me was the temperature that the processor and the battery reached. The processor reached almost 100 degrees when playing, while the battery when disconnected and watching a video or browsing the internet didn't last more than 4 hours with the brightness at 50% and the screen at 60hz, although it is normal for laptops with a dedicated graphics card, it didn't seem right to me.
review_text: The laptop is fine, it is good for gaming, the quality of the materials is very good, the screen is perfect, the only thing that didn't seem right to me was the temperature that the processor and the battery reached. The processor reached almost 100 degrees when playing, while the battery when disconnected and watching a video or browsing the internet didn't last more than 4 hours with the brightness at 50% and the screen at 60hz, although it is normal for laptops with a dedicated graphics card, it didn't seem right to me.

headline: Absolute Tank of a Laptop
text:
Picked this up a few weeks ago and it hasn’t disappointed. The screen is gorgeous, colors pop, blacks are deep, and everything feels smooth whether I’m gaming or streaming. Performance-wise it’s a monster. Games run effortlessly and I can multitask without a hiccup.

The build is solid and has a nice weight to it. The keyboard feels great to type on, which is important for me since I use it for more than just games. My only complaints are the battery life, which isn’t amazing, and the fans, which get pretty loud when it’s working hard.

Overall I don’t regret spending the money at all. It’s fast, it’s beautiful, and it feels like it’ll last me a long time.

headline: Mostly pleased with Lenovo Legion
text: I mostly really like this notebook: it is blazingly fast, most of the keyboard layout is superior to most others, and it has plenty of USB ports (also superior).  But it does not have the required IR to do facial recognition, and the MS Copilot key has replaced the R. Ctrl key, and I have been unsuccessful in attempts to reprogram it.  For those of us who use such keys without looking, that's a problem.

headline: Solid first gaming laptop
text:
This thing is amazing.  I've always had normal computing laptops for work or personal use but this is my first gaming laptop and I'm spoiled.  Screen is crisp, keys are phenomenal (they do feel a bit cramped with full keyboard but it works), performance is great.  You need to have this plugged in or the battery gets consumed pretty quickly playing games but shouldn't be a surprise with whats under the hood.

Would not recommend putting this on your lap as it gets toasty on the underside but the keys are just fine for use even when you're flexing the power of the machine.  Would definitely buy again.

headline: So far so good
text: I’ve only had it for a few days but it’s already 10x better than my MacBook Pro that I paid double the price for 6 years ago. It does things quick and the visuals are incredible. It seems to be decent with multitasking, but I haven’t put it to the real test yet. I only have two issues, the screen brightness and volume buttons don’t work for some reason??? But as I’m troubleshooting, it looks like this is common and can be fixed. I also am having trouble running emulators for older games, but that’s probably more just finding the sweet spot in settings. Seems to run today’s games great!!!
